intro: Acrodiclidium wrightii, commonly known as the Wright's cactus, is a species of flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its spiny, cylindrical stems that store water, allowing it to survive in harsh, dry environments. The plant produces clusters of small, yellowish flowers during the spring and early summer. Its leaves are reduced to spines, which help reduce water loss and provide protection from herbivores. Acrodiclidium wrightii is often found growing in rocky soils and is adapted to full sun exposure.
